text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food
whooshes comm live spanish fire oh
that's right I love Spanish rice but
unfortunately it goes right to my hips
so I decided I would try the recipe
using this ancient grain which is much
slower burning higher in fiber and I
think nutritionally superior but of
course none of that would even matter if
it didn't also taste really good which
I'm happy to report this did so I am
very excited to share this and we'll go
ahead and get started by rinsing our
farro which looks a little something
like this
it sort of looks like brown rice but I
believe it's actually a very very old
variety of wheat which reminds me I'm
always a little bit amused when I hear
it described as an ancient grain since
I'm pretty sure rice is older but anyway
creative marketing terms aside before we
use this what we're going to want to do
is rinse it off in some cold water so we
will transfer that into a strainer and
give it a very thorough rinsing under
cold running water for about a minute or
so and what we'll do once at set is
transfer that on top of a bowl to drain
while we put together the rest of the
ingredients and hopefully that's going
to happen in something like this okay
ideally we're using something that has a
tight-fitting lid and it's safe to use
on the stove as well as in the oven but
if you don't have one of these don't
worry in the blog post I will explain
how you can do this regardless it's
actually very easy and comes out exactly
the same and what we'll do to get this
step started is melt some butter over
medium heat and once that does melt what
we'll do is transfer in a finely diced
onion as well as some kosher salt and
what we're going to want to do here is
saute this for about five minutes or so
or until those onions soften up and
start to turn translucent and generally
when we're doing this we don't want a
lot of color on the onions so if you see
that I'm starting to get brown maybe
turn down the heat a little bit but
anyway we're going to cook our onions in
that butter until they look something
like this at which point we will
introduce our spices in the very same
spices I would use for Spanish rice
which includes some ground cumin some
kind of chili powder mined contain
mostly ancho and some ground Chipotle
which as you may know is a smoked
jalapeno which is pretty spicy and
that's why we're not going to add any
cayenne so sorry and what we'll do is
stir those in and staying on medium heat
we're going to saute that for about a
minute and the reason we do this little
extra step is to sort of
those flavors in the spice as well as
infused our butter a little more
effectively in fact if you're ever doing
a recipe for like a stew or a chili I
think you should always do this with the
spices whether it's written in the
recipe or not but anyway like I said
we're going to cook those spices for
about a minute at which point we're
going to do the exact same thing with
some tomato paste so we will toss in a
few spoons of that and saute it in that
mixture for a couple minutes for sort of
the same reason sure we could add our
tomato paste when we add our broth but I
think by cooking it for a couple minutes
we do deep in that flavor a little bit
so for me that little extra time is
worth it
so I cooked my tomato paste for a couple
minutes at which point we can toss in a
pinch of dry oregano preferably Mexican
and then at this point we can also
introduce our fully drained farro and
what we want to do is stir all this
together and keep stirring until we are
100% confident every single grain of
farro has been coated with that buttery
tomato a spicy onion a mixture so don't
be in a rush and definitely take that
last instruction literally and while you
can do this with any spoon or spatula I
have to say the freakishly small wooden
spoon really does an amazing job
unfortunately I can't tell you where to
get one
since I want to be one of the few people
who uses it but the point is no matter
what you use we'll want to stir that
until every grain of farro is well
coated and then once that's been
accomplished we're going to do two
things we're going to go ahead and dump
in our chicken broth which was cold by
the way no need to heat it up and then
speaking of heat we want to raise our
heat up to high because we want to bring
this up to a simmer and we will give
that a stir and if you did have any
caramelization forming at the bottom of
the pan that's going to be deglaze by
this liquid so you got that going for
you which is nice
and then as soon as that mixture starts
to bubble we'll give it one last stir
which point we can turn off the heat pop
on the lid and carefully transfer that
into the center of a 350 degree oven for
about 55 minutes or so or until that
farro is cooked to our liking and fair
warning
or should I say fair warning
but anyway when you pull off that lid
it's going to look a little weird right
you see that it kind of looks like
someone wrong but that's only because we
have not slept this with a fork yet
which is the next step as soon as we
check to make sure this is cooked enough
so we'll want to grab a fork and dig in
a little bit and give this a little
taste to make sure it's tender and mine
was perfect so this worked out for me
but you're definitely gonna have to
check since you may want yours cooked
even more tender whereas you might have
heard me say before you are the Nero of
your father oh I know I should have come
up with a fresh one but that one's so
good anyway the point is if you need to
pop yours back in the oven for a few
minutes go ahead otherwise it is
officially ready to fork you late so
grab a fork and give it a fluff we
should make it look much more like
something you would eat at which point
assuming you're happy with the
seasonings and it doesn't need any more
salt or a secret shaker Cayenne it is
ready to serve and not to Pat myself on
the back but this really does taste
remarkably like Spanish rice I mean
pretty much an identical flavor profile
with the only real difference being the
texture of the grain which I would
probably best described as an
extra-large rice grain that's slightly
firmer okay almost something like an
extra-large brown rice but without that
nutty flavor which I don't think would
have worked as well here so I went ahead
and proceeded to garnish my platter for
some pictures and since I used some
dried oregano I went with some fresh
oregano sprigs and that my friends I
think is some gorgeous grain and as
wonderful as this was just on the fork
you put this next to some refried beans
and you are enjoying one of the great
combinations of all time not to mention
one of the great vegetarian meals of all
time except I guess for the chicken
broth and the lard and the beans so I
guess we have to go with almost
vegetarian but anyway that's it Spanish
farro if you like Spanish rice you are
going to love this just not as much as
Spanish rice but that's only because
you're going to be comparing the two
which you shouldn't do all right while
inspired by that this is its own amazing
standalone dish and as we covered at the
beginning as far as carb side-dishes go
probably better for you so I really do
hope you give this a try soon head over
to food wishes com for all the
ingredient amounts and wonderful as
usual and as our we enjoy
you
[Music]
